comments.commentBody:
Yours is my fantasy scenario.
If only...

Your analysis is thrown off by your reliance on a very misleading statistic. While misdemeanor arrests are consistently arraigned, charges frequently are not filed or are immediately dropped.  The  45,000 figure far exaggerates the number of cases that get on the calendar. And those that do are seldom gamed. If you expect to game a DUI, expect to be disappointed.

"In 2015, Bronx courts processed 45,000 misdemeanor arraignments but only 98 misdemeanor trials"

What that really means is that they don't do trials. It is 0.2% of cases going to trial. The other 99.8% don't get a trial.

They avoid it by making the situation so impossible that cases go away.

To avoid spending one day each month for over two years sitting at court, almost all defendants will plead to something less costly. A small fine for a lesser charge counts as "a conviction" for prosecutor and police. It gets the defendant out of the problem.

The prosecutor has the other side of the problem. He MUST offer a deal for something better than that. How much better likely depends on things like the crime charged, the evidence, the witnesses available, and the ability of the attorney on the other side. The dealing becomes not guilt or innocence, but some rule of thumb.

Not mentioned in the article is the witnesses. They must be available each month too. If a cop leaves the force, his pending cases likely fail. If they lose track of witnesses over the years, the case will fail. A private attorney will put serious energy into knowing more about the witnesses than the prosecutor, so he knows when they no longer can produce the witnesses to make their case -- married, got a new job, moved, even just died. It is a lot of people to keep track of, for 45,000 cases/year it must amount to near half a million witnesses. They can't do it.

It becomes a game.

Care to explain what the Queen does that makes you so fond of her??
What does she actually do?
As per Woody Allen's old line about 80% of life being just showing up, perhaps the UK Queen shows up in an admirable fashion and that's enough to make the grade.
If only U.S. officials were as well-briefed and well-prepared as the Queen.  Sharp as a tack at 90, Her Majesty!

Why does Sanders have a conspiracy theory for just about everything?  Man, his dog (or the bogeyman) must have eaten a lot of homework when he was a kid or maybe his teacher was really out giving speeches to Wall Street and forgot to grade it.  Honestly, it is getting exhausting.
You have clearly not been to Hillary's website.

I was walking behind a couple last week. I felt bad for him as he had what looked like disfiguring scars on his legs. (I'm in FL, shorts for most of us) As it turned out, he had just really bad tattoos on his legs. Completely indistinguishable from scarring from a reasonable distance.

Who wants that? I don't know, seems odd to me, many tats look like skin damage, not art. And one you go past a little, it's obsessive.

Also, among murders, we know that approximately half of women murdered are killed by their intimate partners - a husband, boyfriend, or ex. If we want to bring the murder rate down even more, focusing on domestic violence would be a wise move.

The number of murders in 2013 was reported by the FBI to be 14,319. The national figure for 2014 was much the same at 14,249. It will be interesting to compare the 2015 number WHEN IT IS RELEASED to automobile deaths in 2015.

The number of passenger vehicle occupants killed in crashes declined by 3 percent in 2013 to 21,132. This was the lowest since 1975 according to the DOT. Yes; you had a greater chance of being killed in an auto accident than in a gang related shooting.

At this point we should be more concerned about fast-tracking the adoption of autonomous automobile rules across the country. The adoption of autonomous vehicles by the public has many advantages - including virtually eliminating the source of way more deaths each year.

Another benefit would be relegating traffic court to the history books and a reduction of highway patrol positions that no longer are needed or fund-able through tickets. Elimination of the need to worry about drunk driving.

Perhaps the FBI could focus on ways to ensure that this country grows economicly. We need people working - not behind bars in a prison. How can we eliminate gangs and organized crime - and replace them with jobs and family. These are the questions the FBI should be contemplating today.

Your argument is noted, but doesn't ask why. Why do various social groups have a higher tolerance for violence. Discrimination, poverty, a distrustful  police force who consider themselves "a band of brothers" and will never report criminal behavior on each other. A justice system that has the largest minority prison population in the world. These and many other contributing factors may create a culture where a higher tolerance for violence becomes the norm.

This rise in violent crime is concurrent with an increase in foreign and domestic populations among us whose social groups have a higher tolerance for violence as a resolution, as well as a period when polarizing views have permeated American life. Social media has been an instrument of fermenting extremes and influencing passive thinkers for some time. Together these factors mean that our police have been dealing with a somewhat more charged environment overall. Many conversations are necessary to sort through this dynamic social time. We need to all slow down to listen, and support sincere leaders taking steps toward rebalancing our communities as we test - and are tested by -change. Our police and law enforcers are trained to handle the instabilities of individuals and groups to maintain community safety with the law as guide. Let's remember they are there to protect us and give each man and woman in uniform the acceptance and respect we ask for ourselves.

America has been a place where the citizens were expected to be afraid of police power - to be obedient and submissive. Man, has this country gone to hell  or what? Cops afraid of citizens. It could be a blockbuster hit on Netflix or YouTube.

There is, of course, the flip side.

If a cop is charged with brutality, he has a video to show he used reasonable force...if the cop used reasonable force.
There is no evidence of cause and effect.  Isn't that what Comey said.  No evidence so......
"Because of less aggressive policing"?  What is that assertion based on?

The sad irony of this that the people purportedly most targeted by aggressive policing - black men - are now being murdered in exponentially higher rates because of less aggressive policing.  So far this has been a zero sum game.

Clearly video leads to police misconduct.

What other explanation is there for all of the misconduct that never came to light before video was commonplace?
I support the good cops and I think videos support them.  I question James Comey's ethics - does he have any standards?

Funny how he isn't concerned about the "chill wind" the FBI creates with its surveillance of minorities. Between this embarrassment in which the public is wrong to hold police accountable and is somehow supposedly to blame for their failures and his zeal to break all encryption, it's time for Comey to go.
I would widen your statement to say that he does not understand the importance of police (and FBI) accountability - period.
And a commencement address has what to do with what Comey said here? Sorry, I don't follow the logic or lack thereof.

No, he is not entitled to any benefit of the doubt. There is no evidence for what he is saying, and if there is, he needs to present it. What we need are more professional police forces using evidence-based practices, not some "wise old sage" decreeing things from on high. There's too much at stake to be subject to one man's folly.

Director Comey's Commencement Address for University of Richmond School of Law last Saturday, May 7 can be found online. He was terrific. Not what you might think. Please give him the benefit of doubt here, Comey is wise and just who we need in a complex time of policing.

“Something is happening,” he said. “A whole lot more people are dying this year than last year, and last year than the year before and I don’t know why for sure.”

I think people are going crazy frankly. Everybody's arguing, everybody's fighting, from youth on to adults. Then you have an overabundance of firearms and drug abuse. These are societal breakdowns and the police are getting called in to somehow sort out the madness. Cops have no idea what's going to happen next and things can go badly for them really quick. With the amount of video being used there's always the chance you're going to come off looking badly. Why risk your career? Of course cops are going to lay off in certain circumstances, it's just human nature.

It's not cops killing people, except in isolated instances, people are killing each other and themselves in big numbers. Statistics bear this out in overdoses and suicide.
If anyone in law enforcment doesn't think he needs data or evidence to get his job done, he is not qualified.
An FBI director who knowingly issues statements not backed by facts engages in behavior so reckless it should be a firing offense. It's time for Mr. Comey to go.
Right, economic conditions cause murders.  That must be why murders actually declined during the depression from 1931 and after.

The director of the FBI believes unless police can get away with murder that they will simply not do what they're paid to do? That's an odd thing to insinuate, but seeing what the average patrol man/woman is paid, it's not a stretch. What's more unbelievable is director Comey takes in about $180,000 a year and makes such dumb comments.
Comey should be fired.  He apparently has no concept of standards of evidence so it is ridiculous that he heads an agency that should rely on evidence.

Whine. Whine. Whine. Cop whining is endless. Police morale is down because too many are caught on tape killing or beating up innocent people or killing or beating up people who didn't deserve the physical mistreatment. Police morale is down because too much transparency about how cops really police (compared to what we see in all these TV cops shows) makes them feel bad about themselves. Etcetera. Policing in the United States needs a complete overhaul.
They are probably doing their basic job, just not going above and beyond.  Can't say I blame them.

Misleading analogy.  An appropriate one would be if doctors stopped helping you in the ER, or surgeons performed less surgeries and let more people die as a result, due to fears about being sued for doing their job.

I agree in general that there is a need for thorough and unbiased review of police behavior.  The airline industry learned that without carefully examining mistakes or near misses in which accidents were narrowly averted, they could not learn what they needed to learn in order to prevent accidents.  Pilots were not willing to report near misses for fear of being disciplined or even losing their jobs.  Once the airlines took a non punitive approach, pilots began reporting near misses and safety improved.  Medicine adopted what is called "just culture" recognizing that most mistakes were not due to incompetence or individual malfeasance, but instead resulted from faulty processes.  But, quality review in medicine is not done in public and in fact findings are protected from discovery by plaintiff's attorneys in many states.  Contrast that with what happens in police cases, where for the most part officers are tried in the streets or in the press before investigation even starts. The challenge is to distinguish legitimate mistakes from reckless behavior and outright criminality be it by pilots, medical professionals or police.  That requires a thorough, timely and unbiased review, away from the public eye until complete, done in an atmosphere protected from politics and the emotions of victims.

Jake – I agree in principle about examinations being done away from the public eye. So, who does them? The police forces themselves? I don’t think so because they have long demonstrated an propensity to circle the wagons, protect their members, and minimize or dismiss allegations of misconduct. Likewise, I have never seen a police force embrace any sort of third-party oversight, be it the DOJ or a civilian review board. Where review boards are created, they are typically toothless watch dogs with no actual authority.

Professionals in other fields, such as medicine and aviation, examine their errors and accidents in an institutionalized way designed to reduce future mistakes. Doctors have morbidity and mortality reviews. Pilots rigorously study accidents to learn about pilot error and mechanical failures. Teachers and professors are evaluated by their students, parents, and peers and administrators in order to improve their teaching performance. Yet, when police officers intentionally or accidentally kill unarmed people or arrest people without cause, we hear that any type of evaluation by the public such as video is harmful to policing and may be increasing the crime rate. Those are scare tactics that reveal how out of touch and unprofessional the police force and culture are. A truly professional and well-educated police force would root out the overly aggressive, racist officers just as medicine and pilots would remove physicians or pilots who were terrible at their jobs. A professional and well-educated police force would implement a rigorous institutionalized process where all officers study and learn from other officers' mistakes -- the mistakes in which officers are killed or injured as well as the mistakes where officers kill or injure others. Instead, we have a culture in which police deny that mistake occur, refuse to study or examine them and blame the mistakes on the people that they killed. We need far-reaching changes in hiring and training officers.

Good, and meanwhile, let's reform Police Training.  Take a page from Sweden & Norway (Yes, they Carry): their training of their cops include 2 to 3 years of University . . . Police University! . . . NOT six months of inadequate Police Academy.

There's a question that's not answered in your data, though: Has crime in Minneapolis gone up as a result? Without that, it would be quite possible to conclude not that police are slacking off and allowing crimes to occur, but that about 1/3 of police activity in Minneapolis amounted to the harassment and even arrest of harmless people.

And if filming of police is curbing the harassment and arrest of essentially innocent people, I'd consider that to be unquestionably a good thing.
Too bad, if the cops don't want to do their jobs, they should be fired and replaced with someone who wants to do their job.

Well, it seems that is precisely the issue in Minneapolis. Just two days ago, the Star Tribune reported: "Through May 2, police records show that 8,504 arrests had been made across Minneapolis. That's compared with a total of 11,879 arrests during the same period last year.

Meanwhile, the number of people who have been stopped, questioned, and frisked also has declined nearly 32% compared with the same period last year.

Lt. Bob Kroll, president of the union that represents the department's 850-plus officers, said last week that intense public criticism of police officers after the shooting death last November of Jamar Clark has led to a morale crisis among the rank and file.

“They’re getting in self-preservation mode, and what that means is you’re just going to emergency calls and being nice to everybody,” he said."
